Tokens.text: You wake up in a room, and you don't know anything about anything. Your mind is a big, fuzzy cotton ball.
You wander around the room for a very long time. A healthy few minutes, then a few minutes longer. You listen to your breathing. You focus and unfocus your eyes as you look at stuff.
There's plenty of stuff in the room to look at (it's a bedroom), but the thing that stands out to you the most is a bookshelf.
You stare, stare, stare, stare at all the books. Each one. You stare for a solid ten seconds at each spine before moving on to the next. Do you want to pick one up? Go ahead:

tokens.innerText: Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?

Tokens.text: You browse through the action section. The store has obviously started down its slow descent into bankruptcy - there are very few patrons in the aisles, and the two-DVDs-for-one-night-for-one-dollar deal is outrageously low (and the lengths they went to promote it is painful - every window is painted with huge explosions announcing this uncannily low price). You aren't seeing anything particularly interesting on the shelf. But, you haven't yet picked out your second video yet and you feel as though you have at least an hour to kill.

Once you've made your selection (Ocean's 12), you wait in line. There's a bookstand in front of the checkout counter, and you look at the titles while you wait. They're all books that have been adapted from, with covers featuring actors from the films. One is

which sticks out to you for some reason. It's a memorable title, but something is nagging at the back of your mind - who told you about this book? Did someone recommend you read this? Is there something else significant about this book? Or was it the movie?
You are in the same room. You're sitting on the bed next to the bookshelf. There's a black cat sitting on the quilt with you. Next to him, a bowl of cat food. He refuses to eat. You're impatient.
You pull a random book off the shelf. You turn your back on the cat, coldly. You look at the book.

by Jeffrey Eugenides. You read the back, the book jacket, and a few of the reviews. It's about a Greek immigrant. After reading more reviews, the name is explained - the main character is intersex. As you sit and flip through the book, the cat sniffs at the bowl. You continue to watch him with your peripheral vision. Eventually, after what feels like an eternity, you glimpse him finally starting to nibble.
You are in the same room. You're sitting on the bed next to the bookshelf. There's a black cat sitting on the quilt with you. Next to him, a bowl of cat food. He refuses to eat. You're impatient.
You pull a random book off the shelf. You turn your back on the cat, coldly. You look at the book.

by Mark Baker, a journalist. You read the back, the book jacket, and a few of the reviews. Apparently, it's a book about the Vietnam War, consisting of interviews from all types of people who were in any way involved. As you sit and flip through the book, the cat sniffs at the bowl. You continue to watch him with your peripheral vision. Eventually, after what feels like an eternity, you glimpse him finally starting to nibble.

You're in a tiny, tiny bedroom. Bright colors are everywhere. There's one other person in the room with you, but for some reason you can't tell who they are. You can't seem to focus on their features.

This person has open a commercially produced copy of Kurt Cobain's private journals. You have mixed feelings about the publishers' decision to sell this book, but you're intrigued nonetheless. The person is showing you a two-page comic of a redneck man listening to the belly of his pregnant wife, ranting about how he hopes the child will be as manly and prejudiced as he is. As he finishes his diatribe and presses his head against his wife's belly, listening for his son (as he is sure the child is) to kick, the last frame shows a muscular leg exploding out of the woman's abdomen and through the man's skull.

You're in a room of some kind, different from the room with the bookshelf - though you can't say exactly how. Your senses are vague. Somebody is talking to you about somebody else, showing you a book as some kind of proof of whatever it is this person has done. It's a book about marine biology, and apparently this person (the one being spoken about) has been selected to go on an oceanography trip of some kind. A competition? For school? The way it's being described, it sounds like a considerable honor. The story ends, however, on a disappointing note - the person was not able to go on the trip. Somebody more qualified for the competition had become available, and the person had to step down.

You're opening Christmas presents with two people. You cannot make out their identities. The person next to you is ripping wrapping paper off a lump - after some shredding, the lump is revealed to be a book wrapped in a shirt:

by Franz Kafka, wrapped in a white t-shirt covered in tiny green letters. In the center of the shirt's torso, the spacing between the letters is shaped like a giant insect. The person looks closely at the letters, half-smiling. After a moment, an exclamation: "It's
On the TV, Julianne Moore jumps around and shimmies to

by Booker T. and the M.G.s as somebody describes to you how the director of this film is actually a pre-eminent fashion designer, and this is his uncannily well-made directorial debut. You hold the book it's based off in your hand.

is, it occurs to you, a thoughtful, interesting movie, but you doubt you'll be reading the book any time soon. You think about expressing this to the other person, but the both of you become sidetracked when the younger male lead comes on the screen and you recognize him as the boy in
You and the other person trip over each other as you both express your bafflement at how much the actor has physically changed over the course of his adolescence.

You're in a classroom. A young, fidgety little skinny teacher with glasses and a bow tie and vest, disappointed that none of his students have done their homework, paces in front of the class. There aren't many students. The ones that are there play with their copies, embarrassed. He tells them that
is a relatively easy read, and that his expectations are not unreasonable. You are, for whatever reason, indifferent.

passages.Name: A Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy

Tokens.text: You're in a grocery store, and you are small. You are eye-level with the checkout line's conveyor belt. As a much lager person shuffles through their wallet next to you, your eye is caught by a green blob on the cover of a paperback. It's got no eyes and it's sticking its tongue out. You ask the larger person, and they say simply, "You know, Douglas Adams hated that thing. The publisher put that on there, and he's been trying to get them to take it off for decades. But it's become so iconic..."
You're in an airport, browsing through a
A whole rack is full of stark white books with four giant bold, colorful letters filling the front covers:

. The author is Haruki Murakami. You see them and you're interested, but as you reach for one, it occurs to you that you'll probably get caught up in the book if you pick it up, and might even miss your flight.

A young man is giving a pitch at the front of a classroom. On his PowerPoint slide is the header "Similar Media" - interesting word choice. The young man explains (or, by his tone, admits) that the game he is describing is basically an interactive version of the book
by Grady Hendrix and Michael Rogalski. The images he's displaying are of an Ikea-like furniture outlet featuring torture devices.

You're in the middle of a cold, silent forest. You're about fifteen feet away from a large, slow-moving river. The ground is covered in a thick bright sheet of snow. The air is sharply cold, and the sky is bright blue. You're sitting on a stump, reading a giant black tome. You're giddy.

You're talking excitedly with another person. You're in a familiar place, and though the person you're talking with is strangely indistinguishable and somehow impossible to identify, you understand that the two of you are very close, and you've never felt closer. You each now have a copy of the same book - and not just any book. This book is colossal. It is a hardback, no jacket, complete with a red ribbon bookmark. The cover features a ring of pink goo, from which images of ladybugs are emerging. As the two of you passionately discuss your favorite aspects or sections of the book, a third person, from the other side of the room, shouts in bewilderment, "But how can you get that much out of it if there are

Everything is dark and murky. Your thoughts are fuzzy. Your movement is slow. It feels as though the air is made of some dark cottony substance. You have a vague sense of being a different person, in a different place.
You're on a Greyhound. You want to just mind your own business and keep reading

but the old woman wants to talk to you. You smile politely as she tells you how much you look like Bob Dylan. She says, "Keep reading books like that one - and Bob Dylan's autobiography - and you'll end up just fine. You'll do just fine."

You're hunting through floor seven of the Harold Washington library. You're not finding what you're looking for. You keep moving down your list - the next one is Thomas Pynchon. This time you find a few. The ones on the shelf are

Tokens.innerText: The Crying of Lot 49, Inherent Vice,

tokens.text: The Crying of Lot 49, Inherent Vice,

Tokens.text: From what you've heard of the density of

you decide that's the one that piques your curiosity the most. You resist the urge to open the book and read the first couple pages, because you want to save the surprise for when you've got time to commit yourself to the whole thing. As you read the back, however, the temptation becomes more and more difficult - the greatest literary mindfuck since
One of the most influential and important literary works of the twentieth century (granted, terms like that are thrown around a lot in the twenty-first century)?
of unique, central characters? How can

Everything is dark and murky. Your thoughts are fuzzy. Your movement is slow. It feels as though the air is made of some dark cottony substance. You have a vague sense of being a different person, in a different place.

passages.Name: The Old Man and the Sea

Tokens.text: You are in the Everglades. Not the deep swamp, but a road - the only road. Cars pass periodically. You are barefoot, carrying your flip-flops in one hand. You have been walking for a day and a half, for no other reason than to have walked all the way through the Everglades. Your head is swimming. All you can think about is the old man's hands. Over and over again, you mull over the image of the man's cramped, blistered hands welded to the string that holds the colossal fish. You picture in perfect detail the ancient, sinewy hands and their death grip on the line. Again, and again. There is no room in your head for anything else. The only halfway coherent thought you can muster is,

Tokens.innerText: my feet are the old man's hands.
Tokens.text: *my feet are the old man's hands.*

tokens.text: my feet are the old man's hands.

Tokens.text: You are lying in bed. This is not the room with the bookshelf. It is larger. The walls are wood paneling, and there is a big open rural vista outside the window. You're literally curled up with a book. As you burn through page after page, thoroughly absorbed in the adventure, the sound of someone talking on the phone in the other room provides a comfortable background noise. After a while, a big dog wanders into the room, wagging its tail.

Everything is dark and murky. Your thoughts are fuzzy. Your movement is slow. It feels as though the air is made of some dark cottony substance. You have a vague sense of being a different person, in a different place.

The room you're in is not a library in the sense of a public facility intended for people to check out and return books, but more in the sense of a room dedicated to books and available for whomever. It is in some kind of facility or workplace, but judging by the young woman in pajamas talking quietly on the phone in the corner, it is open (or at least accessible) twenty-four hours. Is it a place of business? Is it a workplace?

The library room, whatever facility it belongs to, is not well-stocked. After looking through shelf after shelf for what feels like at least thirty minutes (you hope that the girl in the pajamas is not creeped out), you finally strike gold:

by Patrick Suskind. Something familiar in your mind is triggered by this book - did somebody close to you read and enjoy this book? Have you read it before? Did someone famous who you admired like it? You sit down on one of the big chairs and crack it open. As you read, you sneak glances every now and again at the girl on the phone in the corner.

You're at the front of a high school classroom. But you're sitting down, and nobody is looking at you. You're comfortable, you don't feel like you're being put on the spot. You're sitting behind a desk, the teacher's desk. The teacher, a thin man with well-combed gray hair and a bright smile, is answering algebra questions. The students look unapologetically bored, but the teacher doesn't seem to be bothered. He continues explaining polynomials as you enter grades into a computer.

You're nearing the bottom of the stack. The handwriting is nigh-impossible to read, so deciphering names is often extremely difficult (sometimes you worry that you gave students someone else's grade because you simply couldn't read their name). You go down the Excel-like graph, filling in the spaces for name, assignment, and grade. Your cursor goes from box to box, your eyes go from pencilled name to the assignment's grade (written in red marker), and your hands deftly move sheets of paper from one pile to another.
There. The last one is done. Now, in front of the whole class, passively watched by every bored student in the room, you pull out the only non-math book the teacher has in the room:
You find the page where you left off previously.
You are in the same room. You're sitting on the bed next to the bookshelf. There's a black cat sitting on the quilt with you. Next to him, a bowl of cat food. He refuses to eat. You're impatient.
You pull a random book off the shelf. You turn your back on the cat, coldly. You look at the book.
by Harper Lee. This surprises you - isn't Harper Lee famous for only writing one novel,
during her life? You read the back, the book jacket, and a few of the reviews. Apparently
was simply the first draft of

sold like wildfire on its release. It's interesting that people would be so eager to read what the author probably considered a sub-par book, just because that author wrote a single fantastic one. As you sit and flip through the book, the cat sniffs at the bowl. You continue to watch him with your peripheral vision. Eventually, after what feels like an eternity, you glimpse him finally starting to nibble.
A small, small, apartment with a high ceiling and huge windows, overlooking a courtyard. You're embroiled in a discussion with somebody else, someone who you can't quite make out.

The talk is about an author. There's a small shelf of books nearby, and half those books are by this author. The person you're talking about is exploding with praise for the author's imagination, and you find yourself nodding and lamely agreeing. The next book you should read, this person says, is

Everything this person says you like about the author (Chuck Palahniuk) is not only present in this book, but more so than in any of his others. It's dark, it's insane, it's juicy satire, and the book's formatting/point of view is totally bananas. It's probably his best book, and this person doesn't understand why other people haven't given it more credit. You look at the cover. It's some kind of artistic interpretation of a brain stem or subsection of a neural network. It looks like vomit, in a cool way. Even the title,

is one of the coolest you've seen by the author. The other person asks if you care if they spoil something. You hesitate - while you do plan on (and anticipate) reading the book, and you hate spoilers, the suspense is killing you. You're dying of curiosity.

passages.Name: Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?

Tokens.text: You are in the same room. You're sitting on the bed next to the bookshelf. There's a black cat sitting on the quilt with you. Next to him, a bowl of cat food. He refuses to eat. You're impatient.
You pull a random book off the shelf. You turn your back on the cat, coldly. You look at the book.

Tokens.innerText: Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?

tokens.text: Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?

Tokens.text: by Mindy Kaling, the comedian. You read the back, the book jacket, and a few of the reviews. As you sit and flip through the book, the cat sniffs at the bowl. You continue to watch him with your peripheral vision. Eventually, after what feels like an eternity, you glimpse him finally starting to nibble.

The man at the front of the classroom is in his early thirties, and he has slightly shaggy blonde hair. He has a square, handsome face, a slight, athletic frame, and a leather jacket. You have never seen a real person that looked so thoroughly like an 80s action movie lead. The room is slightly dark, and the color scheme is brown. He is prepping the class for the next book - by the amount of warnings and urges for maturity he is layering on, you're pretty sure the book is going to be cool. Lots of drugs, it sounds like. Lots of moral gray areas the protagonist finds himself in. The teacher is describing the book as kind of Kerouac-y meandering disjointed road book, but it will likely be more interesting than the last book we had to read. You don't recognize the book itself, but the title is taken from a lyric in

You are in a car. It is clean. The seats are light gray pleather. The driver is talking about the closed book in your lap. The driver is reasonably excited, describing how cool they think the characters are. You really like the way this person is pronouncing the proper nouns of the story. Hard consonants and long, clear, intense vowels. Harkonnen. Atreides. Bene Gesserit. You've heard these names pronounced differently elsewhere and you're pretty sure the driver is pronouncing them incorrectly, but you prefer these new, more solid ones. You can't seem to be able to focus on this person's features.

You find yourself on, of all places, the deck of a tall ship. Even more surprisingly, you don't seem all that engaged with your surroundings. The ship is moored at a pier, and people are up in the rigging with buckets and brushes, messing with the lines. It's a bright, hot day and the air smells intensely of pine tar. A tan guy with an Aussie hat who looks like a movie star approaches you. "Whatcha readin'?"

You explain that it's your favorite book, and that you read it every year. He smiles and nods, and engages you in a conversation about it - he's curious to know what you consider so powerful that it would warrant a reading every year. As you talk to him, you worry that you're going to get in trouble for reading on the sunny deck while the others are tarring the ratlines. "Hey, uh," you interrupt. "Should I be doing something?"

A person, you can't tell who or what kind, is showing you two books - a novel and a childrens' book. The author of both is a B-list television star. You are feigning interest. As the other person describes why they like the author and why they think he should be taken seriously as a writer, you wait for them to talk about what you really want to hear about.

Eventually, when the childrens' book is opened up, the person hesitantly starts describing their experience with their friend's newborn baby. This is what you'd wanted to hear. The person couches their excitement in their enthusiasm for the author's creativity, but you understand that the person is equally happy to be involved in the life and growth of a baby - which, you are well aware, is a big leap in this person's emotional growth and maturity.
You are in the same room. You're sitting on the bed next to the bookshelf. There's a black cat sitting on the quilt with you. Next to him, a bowl of cat food. He refuses to eat. You're impatient.
You pull a random book off the shelf. You turn your back on the cat, coldly. You look at the book. The front cover is modelled after a pack of Camel cigarettes, except the camel is a woodpecker.

by Tom Robbins. Tom Robbins is an especially weird author from the Pacific Northwest, which is famous for being full of weird authors. You read the back, the book jacket, and a few of the reviews. This is apparently no exception to the tradition of weird books from weird authors from the northwest - it looks like a pretty wild ride. As you sit and flip through the book, the cat sniffs at the bowl. You continue to watch him with your peripheral vision. Eventually, after what feels like an eternity, you glimpse him finally starting to nibble.

You're in a living room with several other people. You're all getting ready to watch a movie. You're the only one who has an idea of what to expect - this movie was described to you as based off a book that was so depressing that it made the reader become a vegetarian. There were no scenes of animal slaughter or animal cruelty (in fact, it's a science fiction book about clones), but the characters were so believable and the world so realistic and the premise so plausible that somehow it made this person reconsider their relationship with animals. Somehow. This person maintained that the movie was equally depressing, if not more so. Knowing these things, you pitched this movie to the eager people in your living room as a fun scifi movie about clones. You try to contain your excitement as one of them inserts the DVD. Your hilariously unfunny prank is about to unfold.

You're in a tiny colorful room, describing to somebody how you simply could not finish it. It was awful. You have read some graphic, nasty books, but this one was too much. Each page was more difficult to read than the last. The person smiles and nods, satisfied. "Good."

Now you're in an earthy hole-in-the-wall bookstore. They don't have what you're looking for, so you're going to try something you've never done - you're going to order the book from the cashier. She is an attractive, cultured-looking thirty-something with a pixie haircut. "And so what's the name of the book?" she asks, super-friendly. You keep a calm, straight face as you answer, "

by the Marquis de Sade." Unfazed, she types it in and starts searching for it in whatever website the store supplies their books from. "It's a Christmas present for someone. As a joke," you feel the need to explain.
You don't know where you are. Someone is describing
by George Bernard Shaw. You're not paying very close attention, and the scene around you is unclear. You're not sure where you are or who is speaking to you.

The library is small, but well-stocked. It's easy to find the fiction section, and there's good selection. You move on down to "H" and browse the Hemingway titles. You know you want to leave with one of these today, but you're not really sure which Hemingway book is the best. You recognize a lot of the titles:

Tokens.innerText: For Whom the Bell Tolls, The Sun Also Rises, In Our Time.
Tokens.text: *For Whom the Bell Tolls, The Sun Also Rises, In Our Time.*

tokens.text: For Whom the Bell Tolls, The Sun Also Rises, In Our Time.

Tokens.text: You look at the back of a few of them. You're pretty sure you're going to pick

was his first collection of short stories. You decide on that one, because you want to see what his writing was like when he was young. You grab the book and start heading toward the front desk, hoping the woman you've developed a friendship with over the library's long, convoluted ordering process (when you needed
for a school project) is working.
You are in the same room. You're sitting on the bed next to the bookshelf. There's a black cat sitting on the quilt with you. Next to him, a bowl of cat food. He refuses to eat. You're impatient.
You pull a random book off the shelf. You turn your back on the cat, coldly. You look at the book.

by Graham Chapman, the deceased Monty Python member. You read the back, the book jacket, and a few of the reviews. As you sit and flip through the book, the cat sniffs at the bowl. You continue to watch him with your peripheral vision. Eventually, after what feels like an eternity, you glimpse him finally starting to nibble.

You're in a room, different from the one you were just in. You're unable to make out much else to distinguish it, but you have a sense of feeling far away from someone or something. The book in your hand,

is giving you a lethargic, jaded feeling - as French books like this one do. You like the book, but you feel like you're plodding through it. Are you reading it on recommendation from someone else? You reread certain parts studiously, as though to be careful to remember those parts for later. Do you think you're planning to discuss this book with someone? Someone you care about?

A dark, musty basement. Low ceiling, huge square footage - maybe half a football field. Divided by black grated partitions, shelves, and looming stacks upon stacks of computer parts. Old parts, new parts, bins of cords and microchips and heat exchangers, gutted towers, ancient hard drives, and in the front, a pitiful few complete-looking laptops. Some keyboards and mice with modest price tags, plenty of speakers with less modest ones. A coffee pot in mid-brew, in a very central location in the front area. In the background, several people with work gloves dismantle electronics over a workbench.
You look at the nearest wall of clutter. There are some books - several books about Linux,
and a few books about languages like Perl or Ruby on Rails. One sticks out to you:
The spine is solid black, as is the cover. You read the back - it's a feminist book, and it looks pretty hardcore. One line on the back particularly impresses you:

Tokens.innerText: it will be over the president's stupid, sickening face.
Tokens.text: *it will be over the president's stupid, sickening face.*

tokens.text: it will be over the president's stupid, sickening face.

Tokens.text: Everything is dark and murky. Your thoughts are fuzzy. Your movement is slow. It feels as though the air is made of some dark cottony substance. You have a vague sense of being a different person, in a different place.

You look up from the book as the train pulls into a station. Below your window, the neighborhood looks very white and affluent. The air looks icy. Is this your stop? You're worried you've gone too far. You pull out a little notebook, pop the cap off a pen, leaf through to a blank page, and poise the pen over its first line. You think carefully. You forgot what you were going to write.

You are struck by the cover - a horrible, ugly, dishevelled bird with tiny, wild eyes and a long sinister-looking bill. You pick up the book and start moving through the building to the checkout station. The walls of the building are entirely glass - looking out the window at the cityscape, you can see you're on at least the fourth story. There are very little colors anywhere that are not provided by the books themselves, until you reach the escalators. This floor's escalators are bright yellow. When you descend to the next set, this floor's are bright green.

You're in a library. It's plain - one story. You're sitting at an empty table crammed behind some shelves. Nobody is anywhere nearby, and you feeel giddy. Like you're there on a whim and you expect somebody to appear and say, "Hey! You're supposed to be somewhere else."
You're reading the first chapter of
After every page, you consider whether you're at a good stopping point. There's a pile of books next to you, and your plan is to sample the first chapter or so of each before it gets dark outside.
You're sitting in a room with Christmas decorations. It's very small, with a high ceiling and big windows overlooking a snowy courtyard.

You're listening to someone (why can't you make out their face?) talk excitedly as you glance at the back of the book, turn it over, and flip through the pages for a while. You're disinterested in what the person is saying, but you are somehow grateful that they are speaking to you so enthusiastically.
A thought enters your head - how can people make what they consider very important points by expressing
about them? Can less be more, or does it mean their point is simple and elegant, or does it mean their point is less important?

You're standing outside a school. It's an old, huge brick building. Two stories, big front entryway. The day is hot. You're sitting on a railing, and there's a big wide runway of green, green grass spread out in front of you. A few students are hanging around in clusters - few enough to indicate that class is not currently in session. A vivacious woman in her forties, with nice boots, approaches you. "I heard that's one of his worst ones," she says, pointing to a book in your hand. Instinctively, you glance down at it. It's the same book you were holding a moment ago by the bookshelf,

You're in a crowded school hallway. You only saw the outside of the other school, but it was enough to convince you that this is a different institution. The walls are stark and modern, high and clean. You emerge from the flood of high-schoolers into a small clearing near the restrooms. You take the opportunity to shovel the stuff you're carrying into your backpack. As you do so, a burly adult man with a goatee and nice, sailorish hair traipses out of the men's room. He looks down at you as you try to squeeze
into the side pocket. "Oh," he says (or rather, some self-assured combination of "Oh," and "Ah," (or really any vowel sound)). "Isn't that supposed to be like one of his worst ones?"

Everything is dark and murky. Your thoughts are fuzzy. Your movement is slow. It feels as though the air is made of some dark cottony substance. You have a vague sense of being a different person, in a different place.
You pace. You look at the stuff in the room. It looks even less interesting now. All you can think about is the bizarre experience you just had. So, do you want to
It's understandable if you need a minute or two to get your nerve up.

Tokens.innerText:
She says something to you, but you aren't listening. You don't know who she is, and you don't care to know. You reach for another book, hoping fervently that the visions will be more vivid this time. You don't want to do anything in this room - or this life - until you've found out more from the books. There's something in there, just out of your reach. You grasp one, indiscriminately.

Nothing happens.

Tokens.innerText:
She stops as she enters the room, seeing you standing next to the books. She looks at you, then at the bookshelf. She says something reprimanding, like "get away from there."

You feel a cool wave of relief flood across your body as you come to understand your relative position in the Universe. Your overwhelming sense of disorientation has evaporated.

Her name is Emily. This is her bookshelf. She is your sister.

tokens.text: She stops as she enters the room, seeing you standing next to the books. She looks at you, then at the bookshelf. She says something reprimanding, like "get away from there."
You feel a cool wave of relief flood across your body as you come to understand your relative position in the Universe. Your overwhelming sense of disorientation has evaporated.
Her name is Emily. This is her bookshelf. She is your sister.

Tokens.innerText:
There is only one explanation for this you can accept. You do not understand it, and it fills you with some kind of unnameable terror. Your inner equilibrium is forced even further off-balance as you try to comprehend what is happening. You do not know why or how you are staring her in the face or what significance the books hold for you, but you are utterly, perfectly certain of one thing:

You are her.

Tokens.innerText:
You're standing in the bedroom with the bookshelf again. You have no idea what just happened.

Your mouth is dry. Your legs are quivering slightly. You put the book back in its spot, carefully. You slide it in with only your index finger, cautious not to touch any of the surrounding books.

You calm your whirring mind, wipe your hands on your clothes, and think. What do you think you should do? [[Look around the room some more,|5 ]] or [[pick up another book?|5]]

Tokens.innerText:
(if: $nothing is true)[The sensations were more clear this time. ]You need more. You need to try this one more time. You have never felt curiosity this strong before - have you? Is this you, in these "visions"? Who are you? Maybe touching the spine of another book will help you find out.

[[But suddenly, the doorknob begins to turn.|6]]
